raw_comment:
I notice that this is a line graph where the dots between the lines represent parents' income rank. The black line is average admissions rate for legacy applicants, while the gray line represents the general admissions rate for non-legacy applicants. I also notice that for the both, you are more likely to get in if you are rich, even though rich legacy applicants still have a boost over everyone else. I wonder why the graph dips near the 90th parents' income rank and how these students' race, gender, and ethnicities, etc. and how that plays into their admissions rate/advantage. The graph's message is that legacy students' are generally more likely to be accepted into top colleges, especially if their parents are rich. 
A catchy headline/title is "Cha-Ching!$ The big bucks help you get into college, as well as your fam (loved ones) who attended the college you want."
ace_sentences: This graph is a line graph.
The dots between the lines represent a parents' income rank.
The black line represents an average admissions rate for legacy applicants.
The gray line represents a general admissions rate for non-legacy applicants.
For legacy applicants, a higher parents' income rank increases the admissions rate.
For non-legacy applicants, a higher parents' income rank increases the admissions rate.
Rich legacy applicants have a higher admissions rate than other applicants.
The graph dips near the 90th parents' income rank.
I wonder why the graph dips near the 90th parents' income rank.
I wonder how race affects the admissions rate of these students.
I wonder how gender affects the admissions rate of these students.
I wonder how ethnicity affects the admissions rate of these students.
The message of the graph is that legacy applicants are generally more likely to be accepted into top colleges.
The message of the graph is that rich legacy applicants are especially likely to be accepted into top colleges.
The headline is: Cha-Ching!$ The big bucks help you get into college, as well as your fam (loved ones) who attended the college you want.
